reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s main remaining optimistic pathway (partial AM-convergence + trade/compromise) by arguing that threat-capability can become endogenously selected-for, shifting bargaining equilibria toward coercion and away from morally-motivated agents. If true, this would substantially weaken the trade-based optimism, though it wouldn’t fully collapse the overall essay (which already treats threats as a major obstacle and also discusses other routes like WAM-convergence). The argument is conceptually plausible and adds a distinct “dynamic selection” mechanism beyond the essay’s mostly static treatment of threats, but it is also speculative and under-argued (no modeling, conditions, or countervailing institutional dynamics), and some of the worry is partially “priced in” by the essay’s existing acknowledgment that extortion can transfer resources even absent execution and that threats may be hard to prevent. It’s clearly presented, focused on one point, and contains little fluff.
title: Trade dynamics may select against non-threatening moral agents over time
